Package ca.cgjennings.spelling.phonetics

Class PhoneticHashAlgorithm

java.lang.Object
ca.cgjennings.spelling.phonetics.PhoneticHashAlgorithm
All Implemented Interfaces:
PhoneticHashProvider
public class PhoneticHashAlgorithm extends Object implements PhoneticHashProvider
Converts a word in a given locale into a "phonetic hash code". Words with the same pronunciation ideally return the same code. The more similar the pronunciation, the more similar the code.

This class uses rules stored in external text files to describe the hashing algorithm for different locales. To support a new locale, add a file to this package with the file name phoneme_rules_XX, where XX is the code for the desired locale. (For example, phoneme_rules_fr_CA would contain rules for Canadian French.) Rules are described in this file as follows (see the English rules for a well-commented example):

Phonetic Hash Rule File Format

A phoneme-rules file contains a set of rules that describe how to convert written words into a phonetic hash code. A word's phonetic hash code describes how it is pronounced; similar-sounding words will have similar or identical phonetic hash codes. The hash code generated by the rules should consist of plain, unaccented capital letters. Each letter represents a basic sound (approximately equivalent to a phoneme).

The sound set used for English, as well as the other locales I have provided rule sets for, uses the following letters:

A B X S K J T F H L M N P R D W Y

These letters generally represent the sound they normally make when used in English words. The letter 'A' represents any vowel; 'D' represents 'th'; 'X' represents 'sh' and 'ch'. Voiced and unvoiced versions of the same sound are often combined (for example, the 'd' sound and the 't' sound both map to 'T').

Note: this is the sound set I have used, based on the well-known soundex and metaphone algorithms in English. If you are modifying a file I wrote, you will want to understand this sound set. However, if you are creating a new file, you are free to define your own sound set and use it however you wish.

A phonetic hash is determined by scanning along a word one letter at a time and applying rules. A rule consists of a pattern to match at the current position and the sound code that it generates. If no code is given, or if the code is '-', then that position is silent and no sound code is generated for it.

The syntax for phoneme rules is
    PATTERN[|PATTERN...] => CODE [OFFSET]
Multiple rules that map to the same phonetic code can be combined with the '|' operator.

Patterns

A pattern typically consists of a string of letters. The letters must match the word in question at the current scanning offset for the rule to apply. The special pattern letter ':' matches any vowel. A rule that starts with '$' only matches at the start of the word. A rule that ends with '$' only matches at the end of the word. (Place the '$' before any '*'s).

To match against letters prior to the current position as well as following it, use the ^ character before the letter that should match at the current position. For example the rule C^H matches when the scanning offset is over an H and the previous letter is C. Note that if a string starts with a $ and does not contain a ^, then a ^ is implied immediately after the $. So $START is read as $^START.

The right-hand side of a rule consists of one or more sound codes (or '-' for no sound) that indicate the sound produced by the letter at the scanning offset.

After the code, a rule can specify a number that indicates how many letters to move the scanning offset forward in the source string. This value must be positive. If it is left off, it defaults to 1, which moves it to the next letter in the string. For example, the rules X => Q; XY => R 2; Y => N would transform 'YXY' into 'NR'.

Rule Priority

If multiple rules apply, the rule with the longest pattern is used. This is usually what is wanted; however, the priority of a rule can be adjusted by appending one or more '*' characters. Any rule names with the same number of trailing '*' characters form a single priority class, with the number of '*'s indicating the class's priority. So all rules with two '*'s will come before any rule with one '*', and so on. If no rule applies, the letter is treated as silent. When two rules have the same length and priority class, the rule that comes earliest in the rule file has priority.

Other Control Parameters

A "control parameter" gives additional control over the phonetic conversion process. The value of a control parameter is defined by including a line consisting of the parameter name, one or more spaces, an equals sign, one or more spaces, and the value to assign.

The following parameters are currently defined. Any parameter name not listed below is reserved for possible future expansion.

hash-length = NUMBER
Hashes generated by the algorithm should include at least this many sound codes. All hashes produced by a given rule set will be the same length; if the number of sounds for a word is smaller than the length, it is padded with '-' characters at the end. A longer hash length makes longer words more distinguishable, but also takes longer to process. Languages with a long average word length (e.g., German) may wish to increase the value. Note that the rule parser will reject extreme values as an error.

kept-doubles = [LETTER...]
Doubled letters are ignored unless they appear on this list. The English rule set defines "kept-doubles = C", so McCall is processed as if it were spelled McCal (doubled C is kept, doubled L is dropped).

Hash Examples

The following is a list of words (or phrases, although the spelling engine only hashes single words) and their phonetic hash, as determined by the English rule file: 
 hegemony                         HJMN----
 heracles                         HRKLS---
 hercules                         HRKLS---
 monkey                           MNK-----
 McCall                           MKKL----
 constipation                     KNSTPXN-
 conversation                     KNFRSXN-
 angel food cake                  ANJLFTKK
 shoggoth                         XKD-----
 Shudde M'ell                     XTML----
 Cthulhu                          KDLH----
 deceive                          TSF-----
 decieve                          TSF-----
 civilization                     SFLSXN--
 civilisation                     SFLSXN--
 Schwartz's Deli                  XWRTSSTL
 antidisenstablishmentarianism    ANTTSNST
 the                              D-------
 they                             D-------

    • convertVowel

      protected static final char convertVowel​(char c)
      This method returns ':' if c is a capitalized vowel, and c otherwise. This implementation only supports the common Latin letter vowels (including common accented forms). A subclass might override this to accept a wider class of characters.
      Parameters:
      c - an uppercase letter which may be a vowel
      Returns:
      c, or ':' if c is a vowel

    • supportsLocale

      public static boolean supportsLocale​(Locale loc)
      Returns true if a hash algorithm can be created for the specified locale.
      Parameters:
      loc - the locale to test
      Returns:
      true if an algorithm can be created for the locale

    • forLocale

      public static PhoneticHashAlgorithm forLocale​(Locale loc)
      Return a phonetic hashing algorithm for a locale. If no algorithm is available for the locale, this method returns null.
      Parameters:
      loc - the locale to obtain an algorithm for
      Returns:
      a hashing algorithm for the locale, or null

    • fromInputStream

      public static PhoneticHashAlgorithm fromInputStream​(Locale loc, InputStream in) throws IOException
      Return a phonetic hashing algorithm by parsing rules from an input stream.
      Parameters:
      loc - a locale that is reported as the rule locale in error messages
      in - an input stream containing a set of phonetic hashing rules
      Returns:
      a phonetic hashing algorithm that implements the given rules
      Throws:
      IOException - if an I/O error occurs while reading rules from the stream
